1458787953124257793.text: 9/ I’m so proud of my Pop. He was a strong, quiet type. And I wish I had tried harder to pierce his veil and learn more about his life. But he led by example. Just like so many great Americans we celebrate today -  Veterans Day 2021. https://t.co/HoHMBeUACM

1458787943775100931.text:
8/ Like most veterans, Pop’s commitment to service didn’t end once he came home.

He built an engineering business in Connecticut, was an active member of his church, helped lead efforts to build affordable senior housing in Wethersfield. And that’s just the tip of the iceberg. https://t.co/6s28qEqzLX

1458787936254808071.text:
7/ He got back to Connecticut in a snow storm, Christmas 1945. The cabbie who picked him up at Union Station in Hartford, and drove to Wethersfield through the storm, wouldn’t accept payment from a returning young vet.

16 months later, his first child, my father, was born. https://t.co/qy7Izc8dSS

1458787928738611204.text:
6/ After Berlin fell, Pop couldn’t come home. There were bridges to be built in the Pacific. In August 1945 he was on a ship bound for the Pacific theater when the bombs were dropped on Japan. 

He was diverted to the Philippines and built bridges there for a few months. https://t.co/xyMY0gNfNv

1458787921025196038.text:
5/ Pop wasn’t infantry, but he was always in harm’s way. His job required him to be constantly on the front lines (since bridges came before the troop advances).

And the speed of construction meant safety wasn’t always first. Here he is after being hit in the head by a crane. https://t.co/NGLNvzpFZq

1458787912657485830.text:
4/ These are photos of the bridges he helped build across Belgium, France, and Germany.

One story Pop told was of the time Patton pulled up to a bridge that wasn’t 100% finished and Pop had to nervously explain to the famously impatient general that it wasn’t safe to cross yet. https://t.co/O7N4qEfXVa

1458787905053368320.text:
3/ After D-Day, one of the primary obstacles confronting the Allies were all the bridges that had been destroyed or damaged by Hitler in an effort to frustrate the Allies’ advance. 

Pop was assigned to Patton’s Third Army to build and repair bridges, and to do it FAST. https://t.co/HkdE6QrGS5

1458787897042214914.text:
2/ Pop had just received his engineering degree from Duke, so he was recruited to join the Army Corp of Engineers.

During a one week leave in December 1943 he married my grandmother. Days later, he was shipped off to Europe. They wouldn’t see each other again for two years. https://t.co/wOFrGxv4Qc

1458787891094728705.text:
1/ As we celebrate Veterans Day, I want to lift up the story of my late grandfather, Val Murphy (his grandkids called him “Pop”), and the unique role he played in World War Two.

Here he is -  a new recruit - in 1943, with my great Uncle Fred. Pop is on the left. https://t.co/1Fra39jkEv

https://t.co/6yjqCDpczh

1456275848877813760.text:
5/ So this idea that the 2nd Amendment prohibits these laws is a completely modern fabrication. 

The people who wrote and approved the Bill of Rights were often the same who supported laws controlling the public carrying of weapons. That's the truth.

1456275846402957320.text:
4/ As an example, Alabama's 1837 law was entitled "An act to suppress the evil practice of carrying weapons secretly.”

Early America was full of laws allowing government to regulate guns in public. It was viewed as a perfectly constitutional exercise of government authority.

1456275844289245186.text: 3/ And it's not like independence from Britain - or the adoption of the 2nd Amendment - changed anything. In the late 1700s, North Carolina and Virginia passed laws restricting carrying guns in public. In the 1800s, 38 more states joined the list.

1456275841697021974.text:
2/ Colonial America was full of laws regulating who could carry guns in America. 

As early as 1686, New Jersey enacted a law against wearing weapons because they induced “great Fear and Quarrels.” Massachusetts followed in 1750.

1456275839272816644.text:
1/ The idea that the Constitution doesn't allow government to control the carrying of guns in public would have been MYSTIFYING to our founding fathers.

Why? Because our founders passed tons of laws regulating the carrying of guns. Here's the quick story.
https://t.co/JOeuIdUiuO

1454762546897068034.text:
5/ When we pass the bipartisan infrastructure bill and the Build Back Better Act, Joe Biden and this Democratic Congress will have made 2021 the most consequential legislative year, with the biggest positive impact on American families, in generations.

1454762546062405634.text:
4/ Oh, and did I leave out that he got universal preschool passed - for all 3 and 4 year olds? He did that too.

“No President could do ALL that in ONE year”, you would say.

1454762545223540736.text:
3/ He got funding for 1M new affordable housing units.

5/ So Aretha is still out of work. She applies for jobs every day but she needs a job that pays a living wage, not a job that keeps her in poverty while making her ineligible for UI or SNAP. 

In short, she needs work to pay. And right now, it doesn’t.

1447982697046061060.text:
4/ But she found that when she got offered jobs, it was for far less than she made at DMV and mostly it was for less than 40 hours a week. 

“I need 5 days a week to pay my bills,” she told me.

1447982696081276928.text:
3/ Aretha liked that job, so she stayed on unemployment hoping she would be rehired. But when that didn’t happen, she started furiously looking for work.

1436660357574139904.text: 10/ Today I’m grieving for all the families who lost loved ones twenty years ago today. And I’m also remembering the day that set in motion the work of millions of Americans chose, in the wake of that terrible day, to try to make their country better and safer.

1436660355191775238.text: 9/ I was deeply uncomfortable about the way in which America over militarized our response to 9/11. But I didn’t want America to withdraw from the world. So I set about the work of properly learning the lessons of Iraq and Afghanistan, and course correcting U.S. foreign policy.

1436660353782452233.text:
8/ People always ask me why I spend so much time working on foreign policy and national security issues. 

It all comes back to 9/11. My generation was formed by it. We are defined by it. The choices we have made since then are derivative of it.

1436660352540942338.text:
7/ But I was a state legislator with no role to play in the biggest issue that affected my generation. I grew frustrated. 

So in early 2005, just over 3 years after 9/11, I decided to make a long shot race for Congress. There I could make a difference I thought.

1436660351316148227.text:
6/ Within two years America was at war in two far off nations.

I knew Afghanistan was the right war, but as my friends were being sent to fight a war of choice in Iraq, I became more and more worried we had made a costly error as a nation.

1436660349953003520.text:
5/ The national conversation naturally launched into talk of retribution. 

That night I watched with my parents as Bush declared “We will make no distinction between the terrorists who committed these acts and those that harbored them.”

This made perfect sense to me.

1436660348254400519.text:
4/ I was glued to the TV the rest of the morning, making occasional calls to see if I could connect with friends in the city. 

Eventually I headed to my parents house in Wethersfield where my parents had cable. We would learn that we lost 3 family friends who were in the towers.

1436660347109314563.text: 3/ As a poor state legislator who spent my entire salary on law school tuition, I didn’t own a proper television or have cable back then. So I pulled out a tiny black and white set and found the antenna only picked up one channel - WTNH.

1436660345788043271.text: 2/ I was at a meeting at Southington High School, just around the corner from my one bedroom apartment. I watched the initial reports of a plane crash on the small televisions in the school’s library. It looked like an accident at first, and I headed back home.

1436660343724457985.text: 1/ I was 27 on September 11, 2001. A second term state legislator. For people like me, in their formative stage of public service in 2001, 9/11 was definitional. It charted our course.

1436652094040289283.text:

1417916003191775234.text:
8/ Yes, the commander-in-chief must always have the right to defend the U.S. and our armed forces under immediate threat of attack.

But Congress - on behalf of the American public - needs to reclaim its power over matters of war and national security.

1417916002080276489.text:
7/ EMERGENCY POWERS: There are 39 ongoing national “emergencies.” Many are legitimate, but there are tons of examples of abuse – like when Trump tried to take money from troops to build a border wall without congressional consent.

It's time to rein in this unilateral authority.

1417916000922738695.text: 6/ ARMS EXPORTS: Right now, we're sending billions of dollars in lethal weapons to other countries – with little to no congressional oversight. But under this proposal, Congress would have to approve the most controversial arms sales.

1417915999807021062.text:
5/ MILITARY FORCE: Our legislation would require that any authorization for the use of force abroad be bound by specific objectives, geographic limits and a two-year sunset.

No more endless wars.

1417915998645194762.text:
4/ At the same time, Congress has often willingly given up its power to the executive branch. That has to change.

Here's exactly how the National Security Powers Act would reset this power imbalance:

1417915997470826498.text: 3/ But over the years, Republican and Democratic presidents have gotten far too comfortable going to war without congressional authorization, declaring vague “national emergencies," and exporting massive amounts of weapons all over the world.

1417915996266971136.text:
2/ Our Founding Fathers envisioned a system where Congress and the executive branch shared power over our national security.

They wanted to ensure that the American people would have a say when it came time to make consequential decisions like sending our men and women to war.
